abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome for the Transport Project
            for Armenia was satisfactory, the sustainability was likely,
            the institutional development impact was modest, and the
            Bank and borrower performance were both satisfactory.
            Lessons learned: An overly prescriptive project, in which
            the Borrower feels compelled to implement measures for which
            they are not ready or in which they do not believe is bound
            to fail or to have short-lived accomplishments. The issue of
            the sustainability of an autonomous road agency able to have
            salary scales outside those in the civil service was
            addressed by the government just after the loan closing
            date, through the establishment of a noncommercial public
            company. The Bank has a very long and not particularly
            successful experience in trying to improve sector planning,
            reducing the level of political influence in project
            selection and improving the allocation of scarce resources.
            The project did have an impact because it provided
            sufficient flexibility to adapt to changing demands.

            EASTERN EUROPE FY03 - ECA GENERAL,TF030428-CANADIAN CTF FOR CENTRAL AND
            EASTERN EUROPE FY04 - ECA GENERAL,TF039391-ARMENIA - TRANSPORT PROJECT,TF021947-RFT PRE-INVESTMENT STUDIES,TF038065-ARMENIA - TRANSPORT-TRADE,TF025535-PHRD-TRANSPORT PROJECT,TF040820-ARMENIA: TRANSPORT PROJECT
5081720.majtheme: Financial and private sector development,Rural development,Urban development

abstracts.cdata!:
The Transport Project in Armenia, will
            improve the main road network, and rail services, as well as
            strengthen the planning capability of the Ministry of
            Transport and Communications, in line with a strategic
            objective of improving infrastructure quality, to enable
            private sector development. The components call for: 1)
            rehabilitation of the national road network, particularly,
            interstate trade routes. It includes engineering design and
            supervision, for civil works such as, surface dressings,
            overlays, and bridge rehabilitation and reconstruction.
            Furthermore, a road safety program will provide improved
            traffic controls, safety education, and a continued
            institutional strengthening of the Armenia Roads
            Directorate; 2) support the Armenia Railways Department
            (ARD), by financing the rehabilitation of tracks, and
            bridges, equipment, and works. Also included is the
            institutional strengthening of ARD, and three separate
            companies, namely on infrastructure management, and freight,
            and passenger services operation. Technical assistance, and
            training will be provided; 3) strengthening of the Ministry
            of Transport and Communications, mainly through technical
            support, and training. An Urban Transport Study will serve
            as the basis for improvement of services in urban transport.
